data.author: Kyle Bucknall

data.text: Hey Rob. I'm 88kg, ride a repurposed budget Alu road bike over all manner of terrain, from single-track to fire-roads and tarmac, loaded with enough gear to keep me comfortable for a week at a time. You'll be grand mate.
data.author: Dee Ball

data.text: Riding 20,000kms plus of touring on modern Aluminum frames, I range in weight from 90-110kms depending on how long the break has been. I've ridden fully loaded (4 panniers) down to just a backpack.... Just about any bike can be used for touring, it's not about the equipment. I met American who has cycled 6,000kms from Russia to Thailand (where I live) on a $5 russian piece of rubbish of a bike.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: Good to hear some sense like this, thanks for saying it. To me it seems like there's too much emphasis in many people's minds about getting the best gear in preparation for the cycling rather than on the cycling itself. It's like a consumerist anxiety, the need to maximize. I'm not immune to it myself and I did ask on this forum about brooks saddles earlier in the year, so I'm not knocking it entirely, there's some good sharing of experiences here. But bottom line is that any bike, any saddle, any whatever, is enough to start the journey. As you say, it's not about the equipment.
data.author: Alan Myler

data.text: 100% waterproof panniers, I beleive is the essential for a happy trip! Other than that, just ride.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: Spot-on. My second hand road bike, panniers, Schwalbe Marathons and other bits of kit came in at just over ¬£200 all-in. And I've happily ridden thousands of miles on it. There's way too much emphasis on kit envy when the truth is that if the wheels turn and it goes forwards, it's pretty much fit-for-purpose. Sure, there are ways you can make your life a little easier with specific buys, but they're all microscopic compared to the adventure of just getting out there and doing it with what you have. üëç

data.text: 100% especially when your starting out. Ride what you have, borrow what you don't. Go on a few rides and find your rhythm. Got to wonder how many people have the perfect bike in the garage and never ridden it, or only one done tour because they didn't enjoy it.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: Even the 100% waterproof panniers are negotiable. We had a lovely week cycling on the Danube cycle path with cheap panniers from Argos and some bin bag liners inside them. As it happened it didn't rain at all anyway. We've since invested in Ortliebs mind you...
